text: I hope for this book that it may come into the hands of those that were
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: kind to my others and that it may not disappoint them.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: --Lord Dunsany
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: POLTARNEES, BEHOLDER OF OCEAN
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Toldees, Mondath, Arizim, these are the Inner Lands, the lands whose
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sentinels upon their borders do not behold the sea. Beyond them to the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: east there lies a desert, for ever untroubled by man: all yellow it is,
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and spotted with shadows of stones, and Death is in it, like a leopard
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: lying in the sun. To the south they are bounded by magic, to the west by a
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: mountain, and to the north by the voice and anger of the Polar wind. Like
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: a great wall is the mountain to the west. It comes up out of the distance
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and goes down into the distance again, and it is named Poltarnees,
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Beholder of Ocean. To the northward red rocks, smooth and bare of soil,
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and without any speck of moss or herbage, slope up to the very lips of the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Polar wind, and there is nothing else there by the noise of his anger.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Very peaceful are the Inner Lands, and very fair are their cities, and
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: there is no war among them, but quiet and ease. And they have no enemy but
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: age, for thirst and fever lie sunning themselves out in the mid-desert,
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and never prowl into the Inner Lands. And the ghouls and ghosts, whose
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: highway is the night, are kept in the south by the boundary of magic. And
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: very small are all their pleasant cities, and all men are known to one
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: another therein, and bless one another by name as they meet in the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: streets. And they have a broad, green way in every city that comes in out
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of some vale or wood or downland, and wanders in and out about the city
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: between the houses and across the streets, and the people walk along it
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: never at all, but every year at her appointed time Spring walks along it
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: from the flowery lands, causing the anemone to bloom on the green way and
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: all the early joys of hidden woods, or deep, secluded vales, or triumphant
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: downlands, whose heads lift up so proudly, far up aloof from cities.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Sometimes waggoners or shepherds walk along this way, they that have come
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: into the city from over cloudy ridges, and the townsmen hinder them not,
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: for there is a tread that troubleth the grass and a tread that troubleth
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: it not, and each man in his own heart knoweth which tread he hath. And in
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the sunlit spaces of the weald and in the wold's dark places, afar from
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the music of cities and from the dance of the cities afar, they make there
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the music of the country places and dance the country dance. Amiable, near
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and friendly appears to these men the sun, and as he is genial to them and
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: tends their younger vines, so they are kind to the little woodland things
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and any rumour of the fairies or old legend. And when the light of some
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: little distant city makes a slight flush upon the edge of the sky, and the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: happy golden windows of the homesteads stare gleaming into the dark, then
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the old and holy figure of Romance, cloaked even to the face, comes down
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: out of hilly woodlands and bids dark shadows to rise and dance, and sends
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the forest creatures forth to prowl, and lights in a moment in her bower
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of grass the little glowworm's lamp, and brings a hush down over the grey
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: lands, and out of it rises faintly on far-off hills the voice of a lute.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: There are not in the world lands more prosperous and happy than Toldees,
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Mondath, Arizim.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: From these three little kingdoms that are named the Inner Lands the young
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: men stole constantly away. One by one they went, and no one knew why they
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: went save that they had a longing to behold the Sea. Of this longing they
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: spoke little, but a young man would become silent for a few days, and
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: then, one morning very early, he would slip away and slowly climb
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Poltarnee's difficult slope, and having attained the top pass over and
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: never return. A few stayed behind in the Inner Lands and became the old
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: men, but none that had ever climbed Poltarnees from the very earliest
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: times had ever come back again. Many had gone up Poltarnees sworn to
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: return. Once a king sent all his courtiers, one by one, to report the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: mystery to him, and then went himself; none ever returned.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Now, it was the wont of the folk of the Inner Lands to worship rumours and
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: legends of the Sea, and all that their prophets discovered of the Sea was
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: writ in a sacred book, and with deep devotion on days of festival or
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: mourning read in the temples by the priests. Now, all their temples lay
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: open to the west, resting upon pillars, that the breeze from the Sea might
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: enter them, and they lay open on pillars to the east that the breezes of
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the Sea might not be hindered by pass onward wherever the Sea list. And
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: this is the legend that they had of the Sea, whom none in the Inner Lands
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: had ever beholden. They say that the Sea is a river heading towards
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Hercules, and they say that he touches against the edge of the world, and
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that Poltarnees looks upon him. They say that all the worlds of heaven go
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: bobbing on this river and are swept down with the stream, and that
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Infinity is thick and furry with forests through which the river in his
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: course sweeps on with all the worlds of heaven. Among the colossal trunks
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of those dark trees, the smallest fronds of whose branches are man nights,
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: there walk the gods. And whenever its thirst, glowing in space like a
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: great sun, comes upon the beast, the tiger of the gods creeps down to the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: river to drink. And the tiger of the gods drinks his fill loudly, whelming
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: worlds the while, and the level of the river sinks between its banks ere
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the beast's thirst is quenched and ceases to glow like a sun. And many
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: worlds thereby are heaped up dry and stranded, and the gods walk not among
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: them evermore, because they are hard to their feet. These are the worlds
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that have no destiny, whose people know no god. And the river sweeps
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: onwards ever. And the name of the River is Oriathon, but men call it
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Ocean. This is the Lower Faith of the Inner Lands. And there is a Higher
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Faith which is not told to all. Oriathon sweeps on through the forests of
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Infinity and all at once falls roaring over an Edge, whence Time has long
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ago recalled his hours to fight in his war with the gods; and falls unlit
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: by the flash of nights and days, with his flood unmeasured by miles, into
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the deeps of nothing.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Now as the centuries went by and the one way by which a man could climb
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Poltarnees became worn with feet, more and more men surmounted it, not to
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: return. And still they knew not in the Inner Lands upon what mystery
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Poltarnees looked. For on a still day and windless, while men walked
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: happily about their beautiful streets or tended flocks in the country,
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: suddenly the west wind would bestir himself and come in from the Sea. And
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: he would come cloaked and grey and mournful and carry to someone the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hungry cry of the Sea calling out for bones of men. And he that heard it
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: would move restlessly for some hours, and at last would rise suddenly,
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: irresistibly up, setting his face to Poltarnees, and would say, as is the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: custom of those lands when men part briefly, "Till a man's heart
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: remembereth," which means "Farewell for a while"; but those that loved
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: him, seeing his eyes on Poltarnees, would answer sadly, "Till the gods
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: forget," which means "Farewell."
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Now the king of Arizim had a daughter who played with the wild wood
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: flowers, and with the fountains in her father's court, and with the little
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: blue heaven-birds that came to her doorway in the winter to shelter from
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the snow. And she was more beautiful than the wild wood flowers, or than
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: all the fountains in her father's court, or than the blue heaven-birds in
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: their full winter plumage when they shelter from the snow. The old wise
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: kings of Mondath and of Toldees saw her once as she went lightly down the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: little paths of her garden, and turning their gaze into the mists of
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: thought, pondered the destiny of their Inner Lands. And they watched her
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: closely by the stately flowers, and standing alone in the sunlight, and
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: passing and repassing the strutting purple birds that the king's fowlers
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: had brought from Asagehon. When she was of the age of fifteen years the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: King of Mondath called a council of kings. And there met with him the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: kings of Toldees and Arizim. And the King of Mondath in his Council said:
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "The call of the unappeased and hungry Sea (and at the word 'Sea' the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: three kings bowed their heads) lures every year out of our happy kingdoms
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: more and more of our men, and still we know not the mystery of the Sea,
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and no devised oath has brought one man back. Now thy daughter, Arizim, is
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: lovelier than the sunlight, and lovelier than those stately flowers of
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: thine that stand so tall in her garden, and hath more grace and beauty
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: than those strange birds that the venturous fowlers bring in creaking
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wagons out of Asagehon, whose feathers are alternate purple and white.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Now, he that shall love thy daughter, Hilnaric, whoever he shall be, is
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the man to climb Poltarnees and return, as none hath ever before, and tell
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: us upon what Poltarnees looks; for it may be that they daughter is more
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: beautiful than the Sea."
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then from his Seat of Council arose the King of Arizim. He said: "I fear
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that thou hast spoken blasphemy against the Sea, and I have a dread that
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ill will come of it. Indeed I had not thought she was so fair. It is such
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: a short while ago that she was quite a small child with her hair still
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: unkempt and not yet attired in the manner of princesses, and she would go
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: up into the wild woods unattended and come back with her robes unseemly
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and all torn, and would not take reproof with a humble spirit, but made
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: grimaces even in my marble court all set about with fountains."
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then said the King of Toldees:
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Let us watch more closely and let us see the Princess Hilnaric in the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: season of the orchard-bloom when the great birds go by that know the Sea,
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to rest in our inland places; and if she be more beautiful than the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sunrise over our folded kingdoms when all the orchards bloom, it may be
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that she is more beautiful than the Sea."
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the King of Arizim said:
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "I fear this is terrible blasphemy, yet will I do as you have decided in
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: council."
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the season of the orchard-bloom appeared. One night the King of Arizim
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: called his daughter forth on his outer balcony of marble. And the moon was
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: rising huge and round and holy over dark woods, and all the fountains were
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: singing to the night. And the moon touched the marble palace gables, and
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: they glowed in the land. And the moon touched the heads of all the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: fountains, and the grey columns broke into fairy lights. And the moon left
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the dark ways of the forest and lit the whole white palace and its
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: fountains and shone on the forehead of the Princess, and the palace of
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Arizim glowed afar, and the fountains became columns of gleaming jewels
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and song. And the moon made a music at its rising, but it fell a little
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: short of mortal ears. And Hilnaric stood there wondering, clad in white,
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with the moonlight shining on her forehead; and watching her from the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: shadows on the terrace stood the kings of Mondath and Toldees. They said.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "She is more beautiful than the moonrise." And the season of the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: orchard-bloom appeared. One night the King of Arizim called his daughter
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: forth on his outer balcony of marble. And the moon was rising huge and
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: round and holy over dark woods, and all the fountains were singing to the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: night. And the moon touched the marble palace gables, and they glowed in
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the land. And the moon touched the heads of all the fountains, and the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: grey columns broke into fairy lights. And the moon left the dark ways of
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the forest and lit the whole white palace and its fountains and shone on
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the forehead of the Princess, and the palace of Arizim glowed afar, and
title: A Dreamer's Tales

text: the fountains became columns of gleaming jewels and song. And the moon
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: made a music at its rising, but it fell a little short of mortal ears. And
title: A Dreamer's Tales

text: Hilnaric stood there wondering, clad in white, with the moonlight shining
title: A Dreamer's Tales

text: on her forehead; and watching her from the shadows on the terrace stood
title: A Dreamer's Tales

text: the kings of Mondath and Toldees. They said:
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "She is more beautiful than the moonrise." And on another day the King of
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Arizim bade his daughter forth at dawn, and they stood again upon the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: balcony. And the sun came up over a world of orchards, and the sea-mists
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: went back over Poltarnees to the Sea; little wild voices arose in all the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: thickets, the voices of the fountains began to die, and the song arose, in
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: all the marble temples, of the birds that are sacred to the Sea. And
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Hilnaric stood there, still glowing with dreams of heaven.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "She is more beautiful," said the kings, "than morning."
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Yet one more trial they made of Hilnaric's beauty, for they watched her on
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the terraces at sunset ere yet the petals of the orchards had fallen, and
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: all along the edge of neighbouring woods the rhododendron was blooming
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with the azalea. And the sun went down under craggy Poltarnees, and the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sea-mist poured over his summit inland. And the marble temples stood up
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: clear in the evening, but films of twilight were drawn between the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: mountain and the city. Then from the Temple ledges and eaves of palaces
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the bats fell headlong downwards, then spread their wings and floated up
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and down through darkening ways; lights came blinking out in golden
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: windows, men cloaked themselves against the grey sea-mist, the sound of
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: small songs arose, and the face of Hilnaric became a resting-place for
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: mysteries and dreams.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Than all these things," said the kings, "she is more lovely: but who can
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: say whether she is lovelier than the Sea?"
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Prone in a rhododendron thicket at the edge of the palace lawns a hunter
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: had waited since the sun went down. Near to him was a deep pool where the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hyacinths grew and strange flowers floated upon it with broad leaves; and
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: there the great bull gariachs came down to drink by starlight; and,
title: A Dreamer's Tales

title: A Dreamer's Tales

title: A Dreamer's Tales

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: A Dreamer's Tales

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: A Dreamer's Tales

title: A Dreamer's Tales

title: A Dreamer's Tales

title: A Dreamer's Tales

title: A Dreamer's Tales

title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: A Dreamer's Tales

title: A Dreamer's Tales

title: A Dreamer's Tales

title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: A Dreamer's Tales

author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Pen-Kai and Blut, and the wandering streets of Mlo, where priests
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: propitiate the avalanche with wine and maize. Then night came down over
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the plains of Tlun, and we saw the lights of Cappadarnia. We heard the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Pathnites beating upon drums as we passed Imaut and Golzunda, then all but
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the helmsman slept. And villages scattered along the banks of the Yann
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: heard all that night in the helmsman's unknown tongue the little songs of
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: cities that they knew not.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: I awoke before dawn with a feeling that I was unhappy before I remembered
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: why. Then I recalled that by the evening of the approaching day, according
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to all foreseen probabilities, we should come to Bar-Wul-Yann, and I
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: should part from the captain and his sailors. And I had liked the man
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: because he had given me of his yellow wine that was set apart among his
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sacred things, and many a story he had told me about his fair Belzoond
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: between the Acroctian hills and the Hian Min. And I had liked the ways
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that his sailors had, and the prayers that they prayed at evening side by
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: side, grudging not one another their alien gods. And I had a liking too
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: for the tender way in which they often spoke of Durl and Duz, for it is
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: good that men should love their native cities and the little hills that
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hold those cities up.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And I had come to know who would meet them when they returned to their
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: homes, and where they thought the meetings would take place, some in a
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: valley of the Acroctian hills where the road comes up from Yann, others in
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the gateway of one or another of the three cities, and others by the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: fireside in the home. And I thought of the danger that had menaced us all
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: alike outside Perdondaris, a danger that, as things have happened, was
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: very real.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And I thought too of the helmsman's cheery song in the cold and lonely
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: night, and how he had held our lives in his careful hands. And as I
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: thought of this the helmsman ceased to sing, and I looked up and saw a
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: pale light had appeared in the sky, and the lonely night had passed; and
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the dawn widened, and the sailors awoke.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And soon we saw the tide of the Sea himself advancing resolute between
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Yann's borders, and Yann sprang lithely at him and they struggled awhile;
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: then Yann and all that was his were pushed back northward, so that the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sailors had to hoist the sails and, the wind being favorable, we still
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: held onwards.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And we passed Gondara and Narl and Haz. And we saw memorable, holy Golnuz,
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and heard the pilgrims praying.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: When we awoke after the midday rest we were coming near to Nen, the last
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the cities on the River Yann. And the jungle was all about us once
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: again, and about Nen; but the great Mloon ranges stood up over all things,
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and watched the city from beyond the jungle.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Here we anchored, and the captain and I went up into the city and found
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that the Wanderers had come into Nen.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the Wanderers were a weird, dark, tribe, that once in every seven
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: years came down from the peaks of Mloon, having crossed by a pass that is
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: known to them from some fantastic land that lies beyond. And the people of
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Nen were all outside their houses, and all stood wondering at their own
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: streets. For the men and women of the Wanderers had crowded all the ways,
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and every one was doing some strange thing. Some danced astounding dances
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that they had learned from the desert wind, rapidly curving and swirling
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: till the eye could follow no longer. Others played upon instruments
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: beautiful wailing tunes that were full of horror, which souls had taught
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: them lost by night in the desert, that strange far desert from which the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Wanderers came.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: None of their instruments were such as were known in Nen nor in any part
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the region of the Yann; even the horns out of which some were made were
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of beasts that none had seen along the river, for they were barbed at the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: tips. And they sang, in the language of none, songs that seemed to be akin
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to the mysteries of night and to the unreasoned fear that haunts dark
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: places.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Bitterly all the dogs of Nen distrusted them. And the Wanderers told one
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: another fearful tales, for though no one in Nen knew ought of their
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: language yet they could see the fear on the listeners' faces, and as the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: tale wound on the whites of their eyes showed vividly in terror as the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: eyes of some little beast whom the hawk has seized. Then the teller of the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: tale would smile and stop, and another would tell his story, and the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: teller of the first tale's lips would chatter with fear. And if some
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: deadly snake chanced to appear the Wanderers would greet him as a brother,
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and the snake would seem to give his greetings to them before he passed on
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: again. Once that most fierce and lethal of tropic snakes, the giant
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: lythra, came out of the jungle and all down the street, the central street
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of Nen, and none of the Wanderers moved away from him, but they all played
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sonorously on drums, as though he had been a person of much honour; and
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the snake moved through the midst of them and smote none.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Even the Wanderers' children could do strange things, for if any one of
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: them met with a child of Nen the two would stare at each other in silence
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with large grave eyes; then the Wanderers' child would slowly draw from
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: his turban a live fish or snake. And the children of Nen could do nothing
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of that kind at all.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Much I should have wished to stay and hear the hymn with which they greet
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the night, that is answered by the wolves on the heights of Mloon, but it
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: was now time to raise the anchor again that the captain might return from
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Bar-Wul-Yann upon the landward tide. So we went on board and continued
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: down the Yann. And the captain and I spoke little, for we were thinking of
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: our parting, which should be for long, and we watched instead the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: splendour of the westerning sun. For the sun was a ruddy gold, but a faint
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: mist cloaked the jungle, lying low, and into it poured the smoke of the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: little jungle cities, and the smoke of them met together in the mist and
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: joined into one haze, which became purple, and was lit by the sun, as the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: thoughts of men become hallowed by some great and sacred thing. Some times
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: one column from a lonely house would rise up higher than the cities'
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: smoke, and gleam by itself in the sun.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And now as the sun's last rays were nearly level, we saw the sight that I
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: had come to see, for from two mountains that stood on either shore two
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: cliffs of pink marble came out into the river, all glowing in the light of
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the low sun, and they were quite smooth and of mountainous altitude, and
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: they nearly met, and Yann went tumbling between them and found the sea.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And this was Bar-Wul-Yann, the Gate of Yann, and in the distance through
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that barrier's gap I saw the azure indescribable sea, where little
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: fishing-boats went gleaming by.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the sun set, and the brief twilight came, and the exultation of the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: glory of Bar-Wul-Yann was gone, yet still the pink cliffs glowed, the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: fairest marvel that the eye beheld--and this in a land of wonders. And
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: soon the twilight gave place to the coming out of stars, and the colours
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of Bar-Wul-Yann went dwindling away. And the sight of those cliffs was to
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: me as some chord of music that a master's hand had launched from the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: violin, and which carries to Heaven or Faery the tremulous spirits of men.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And now by the shore they anchored and went no further, for they were
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sailors of the river and not of the sea, and knew the Yann but not the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: tides beyond.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the time was come when the captain and I must part, he to go back to
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: his fair Belzoond in sight of the distant peaks of the Hian Min, and I to
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: find my way by strange means back to those hazy fields that all poets
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: know, wherein stand small mysterious cottages through whose windows,
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: looking westwards, you may see the fields of men, and looking eastwards
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: see glittering elfin mountains, tipped with snow, going range on range
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: into the region of Myth, and beyond it into the kingdom of Fantasy, which
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: pertain to the Lands of Dream. Long we regarded one another, knowing that
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: we should meet no more, for my fancy is weakening as the years slip by,
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and I go ever more seldom into the Lands of Dream. Then we clasped hands,
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: uncouthly on his part, for it is not the method of greeting in his
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: country, and he commended my soul to the care of his own gods, to his
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: little lesser gods, the humble ones, to the gods that bless Belzoond.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: THE SWORD AND THE IDOL
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: It was a cold winter's evening late in the Stone Age; the sun had gone
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: down blazing over the plains of Thold; there were no clouds, only the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: chill blue sky and the imminence of stars; and the surface of the sleeping
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Earth began to harden against the cold of the night. Presently from their
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: lairs arose, and shook themselves and went stealthily forth, those of
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Earth's children to whom it is the law to prowl abroad as soon as the dusk
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: has fallen. And they went pattering softly over the plain, and their eyes
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: shone in the dark, and crossed and recrossed one another in their courses.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Suddenly there became manifest in the midst of the plain that fearful
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: portent of the presence of Man--a little flickering fire. And the children
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of Earth who prowl abroad by night looked sideways at it and snarled and
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: edged away; all but the wolves, who came a little nearer, for it was
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: winter and the wolves were hungry, and they had come in thousands from the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: mountains, and they said in their hearts, "We are strong." Around the fire
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: a little tribe was encamped. They, too, had come from the mountains, and
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: from lands beyond them, but it was in the mountains that the wolves first
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: winded them; they picked up bones at first that the tribe had dropped, but
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: they were closer now and on all sides. It was Loz who had lit the fire. He
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: had killed a small furry beast, hurling his stone axe at it, and had
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: gathered a quantity of reddish-brown stones, and had laid them in a long
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: row, and placed bits of the small beast all along it; then he lit a fire
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: on each side, and the stones heated, and the bits began to cook. It was at
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: this time that the tribe noticed that the wolves who had followed them so
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: far were no longer content with the scraps of deserted encampments. A line
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of yellow eyes surrounded them, and when it moved it was to come nearer.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: So the men of the tribe hastily tore up brushwood, and felled a small tree
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with their flint axes, and heaped it all over the fire that Loz had made,
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and for a while the great heap hid the flame, and the wolves came trotting
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in and sat down again on their haunches much closer than before; and the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: fierce and valiant dogs that belonged to the tribe believed that their end
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: was about to come while fighting, as they had long since prophesied it
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: would. Then the flame caught the lofty stack of brushwood, and rushed out
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of it, and ran up the side of it, and stood up haughtily far over the top,
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and the wolves seeing this terrible ally of Man reveling there in his
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: strength, and knowing nothing of this frequent treachery to his masters,
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: went slowly away as though they had other purposes. And for the rest of
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that night the dogs of the encampment cried out to them and besought them
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to come back. But the tribe lay down all round the fire under thick furs
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and slept. And a great wind arose and blew into the roaring heart of the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: fire till it was red no longer, but all pallid with heat. With the dawn
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the tribe awoke.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Loz might have known that after such a mighty conflagration nothing could
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: remain of his small furry beast, but there was hunger in him and little
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: reason as he searched among the ashes. What he found there amazed him
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: beyond measure; there was no meat, there was not even his row of
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: reddish-brown stones, but something longer than a man's leg and narrower
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: than his hand, was lying there like a great flattened snake. When Loz
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: looked at its thin edges and saw that it ran to a point, he picked up
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: stones to chip it and make it sharp. It was the instinct of Loz to sharpen
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: things. When he found that it could not be chipped his wonderment
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: increased. It was many hours before he discovered that he could sharpen
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the edges by rubbing them with a stone; but at last the point was sharp,
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and all one side of it except near the end, where Loz held it in his hand.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And Loz lifted it and brandished it, and the Stone Age was over. That
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: afternoon in the little encampment, just as the tribe moved on, the Stone
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Age passed away, which, for perhaps thirty or forty thousand years, had
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: slowly lifted Man from among the beasts and left him with his supremacy
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: beyond all hope of reconquest.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: It was not for many days that any other man tried to make for himself an
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: iron sword by cooking the same kind of small furry beast that Loz had
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: tried to cook. It was not for many years that any thought to lay the meat
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: along stones as Loz had done; and when they did, being no longer on the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: plains of Thold, they used flints or chalk. It was not for many
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: generations that another piece of iron ore was melted and the secret
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: slowly guessed. Nevertheless one of Earth's many veils was torn aside by
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Loz to give us ultimately the steel sword and the plough, machinery and
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: factories; let us not blame Loz if we think that he did wrong, for he did
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: all in ignorance. The tribe moved on until it came to water, and there it
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: settled down under a hill, and they built their huts there. Very soon they
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: had to fight with another tribe, a tribe that was stronger than they; but
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the sword of Loz was terrible and his tribe slew their foes. You might
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: make one blow at Loz, but then would come one thrust from that iron sword,
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and there was no way of surviving it. No one could fight with Loz. And he
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: became ruler of the tribe in the place of Iz, who hitherto had ruled it
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with his sharp axe, as his father had before him.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Now Loz begat Lo, and in his old age gave his sword to him, and Lo ruled
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the tribe with it. And Lo called the name of the sword Death, because it
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: was so swift and terrible.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And Iz begat Ird, who was of no account. And Ird hated Lo because he was
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of no account by reason of the iron sword of Lo.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: One night Ird stole down to the hut of Lo, carrying his sharp axe, and he
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: went very softly, but Lo's dog, Warner, heard him coming, and he growled
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: softly by his master's door. When Ird came to the hut he heard Lo talking
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: gently to his sword. And Lo was saying, "Lie still, Death. Rest, rest, old
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sword," and then, "What, again, Death? Be still. Be still."
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And then again: "What, art thou hungry, Death? Or thirsty, poor old sword?
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Soon, Death, soon. Be still only a little."
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: But Ird fled, for he did not like the gentle tone of Lo as he spoke to his
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sword.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And Lo begat Lod. And when Lo died Lod took the iron sword and ruled the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: tribe.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And Ird begat Ith, who was of no account, like his father.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Now when Lod had smitten a man or killed a terrible beast, Ith would go
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: away for a while into the forest rather than hear the praises that would
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: be given to Lod.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And once, as Ith sat in the forest waiting for the day to pass, he
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: suddenly thought he saw a tree trunk looking at him as with a face. And
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Ith was afraid, for trees should not look at men. But soon Ith saw that it
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: was only a tree and not a man, though it was like a man. Ith used to speak
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to this tree, and tell it about Lod, for he dared not speak to any one
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: else about him. And Ith found comfort in speaking about Lod.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: One day Ith went with his stone axe into the forest, and stayed there many
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: days.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: He came back by night, and the next morning when the tribe awoke they saw
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: something that was like a man and yet was not a man. And it sat on the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hill with its elbows pointing outwards and was quite still. And Ith was
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: crouching before it, and hurriedly placing before it fruits and flesh, and
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: then leaping away from it and looking frightened. Presently all the tribe
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: came out to see, but dared not come quite close because of the fear that
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: they saw on the face of Ith. And Ith went to his hut, and came back again
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with a hunting spear-head and valuable small stone knives, and reached out
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and laid them before the thing that was like a man, and then sprang away
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: from it.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And some of the tribe questioned Ith about the still thing that was like a
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: man, and Ith said, "This is Ged." Then they asked, "Who is Ged?" and Ith
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: said, "Ged sends the crops and the rain; and the sun and the moon are
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Ged's."
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then the tribe went back to their huts, but later in the day some came
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: again, and they said to Ith, "Ged is only as we are, having hands and
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: feet." And Ith pointed to the right hand of Ged, which was not as his
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: left, but was shaped like the paw of a beast, and Ith said, "By this ye
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: may know that he is not as any man."
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then they said, "He is indeed Ged." But Lod said, "He speaketh not, nor
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: doth he eat," and Ith answered, "The thunder is his voice and the famine
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: is his eating."
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: After this the tribe copied Ith, and brought little gifts of meat to Ged;
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and Ith cooked them before him that Ged might smell the cooking.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: One day a great thunderstorm came trampling up from the distance and raged
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: among the hills, and the tribe all hid away from it in their huts. And Ith
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: appeared among the huts looking unafraid. And Ith said little, but the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: tribe thought that he had expected the terrible storm because the meat
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that they had laid before Ged had been tough meat, and not the best parts
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the beasts they slew.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And Ged grew to have more honour among the tribe than Lod. And Lod was
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: vexed.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: One night Lod arose when all were asleep, and quieted his dog, and took
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: his iron sword and went away to the hill. And he came on Ged in the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: starlight, sitting still, with his elbows pointing outwards, and his
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: beast's paw, and the mark of the fire on the ground where his food had
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: been cooked.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And Lod stood there for a while in great fear, trying to keep to his
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: purpose. Suddenly he stepped up close to Ged and lifted his iron sword,
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and Ged neither hit nor shrank. Then the thought came into Lod's mind,
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Ged does not hit. What will Ged do instead?"
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And Lod lowered his sword and struck not, and his imagination began to
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: work on that "What will Ged do instead?"
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the more Lod thought, the worse was his fear of Ged.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And Lod ran away and left him.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Lod still ruled the tribe in battle or in the hunt, but the chiefest
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: spoils of battle were given to Ged, and the beasts that they slew were
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Ged's; and all questions that concerned war or peace, and questions of law
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and disputes, were always brought to him, and Ith gave the answers after
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: speaking to Ged by night.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: At last Ith said, the day after an eclipse, that the gifts which they
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: brought to Ged were not enough, that some far greater sacrifice was
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: needed, that Ged was very angry even now, and not to be appeased by any
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ordinary sacrifice.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And Ith said that to save the tribe from the anger of Ged he would speak
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to Ged that night, and ask him what new sacrifice he needed.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Deep in his heart Lod shuddered, for his instinct told him that Ged wanted
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Lod's only son, who should hold the iron sword when Lod was gone.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: No one would dare touch Lod because of the iron sword, but his instinct
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: said in his slow mind again and again, "Ged loves Ith. Ith has said so.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Ith hates the sword-holders."
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Ith hates the sword-holders. Ged loves Ith."
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Evening fell and the night came when Ith should speak with Ged, and Lod
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: became ever surer of the doom of his race.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: He lay down but could not sleep.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Midnight had barely come when Lod arose and went with his iron sword again
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to the hill.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And there sat Ged. Had Ith been to him yet? Ith whom Ged loved, who hated
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the sword-holders.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And Lod looked long at the old sword of iron that had come to his
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: grandfather on the plains of Thold.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Good-bye, old sword! And Lod laid it on the knees of Ged, then went away.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And when Ith came, a little before dawn, the sacrifice was found
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: acceptable unto Ged.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: THE IDLE CITY
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: There was once a city which was an idle city, wherein men told vain tales.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And it was that city's custom to tax all men that would enter in, with the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: toll of some idle story in the gate.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: So all men paid to the watchers in the gate the toll of an idle story, and
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: passed into the city unhindered and unhurt. And in a certain hour of the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: night when the king of that city arose and went pacing swiftly up and down
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the chamber of his sleeping, and called upon the name of the dead queen,
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: then would the watchers fasten up the gate and go into that chamber to the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: king, and, sitting on the floor, would tell him all the tales that they
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: had gathered. And listening to them some calmer mood would come upon the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: king, and listening still he would lie down again and at last fall asleep,
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and all the watchers silently would arise and steal away from the chamber.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: A while ago wandering, I came to the gate of that city. And even as I came
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: a man stood up to pay his toll to the watchers. They were seated
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: cross-legged on the ground between him and the gate, and each one held a
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: spear. Near him two other travellers sat on the warm sand waiting. And the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: man said:
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Now the city of Nombros forsook the worship of the gods and turned
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: towards God. So the gods threw their cloaks over their faces and strode
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: away from the city, and going into the haze among the hills passed through
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the trunks of the olive groves into the sunset. But when they had already
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: left the Earth, they turned and looked through the gleaming folds of the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: twilight for the last time at their city; and they looked half in anger
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and half in regret, then turned and went away for ever. But they sent back
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: a Death, who bore a scythe, saying to it: 'Slay half in the city that
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: forsook us, but half of them spare alive that they may yet remember their
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: old forsaken gods.'
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "But God sent a destroying angel to show that He was God, saying unto him:
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: 'Go into that city and slay half of the dwellers therein, yet spare a half
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of them that they may know that I am God.'
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "And at once the destroying angel put his hand to his sword, and the sword
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: came out of the scabbard with a deep breath, like to the breath that a
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: broad woodman takes before his first blow at some giant oak. Thereat the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: angel pointed his arms downwards, and bending his head between them, fell
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: forward from Heaven's edge, and the spring of his ankles shot him
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: downwards with his wings furled behind him. So he went slanting earthward
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: through the evening with his sword stretched out before him, and he was
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: like a javelin that some hunter hath hurled that returneth again to the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: earth: but just before he touched it he lifted his head and spread his
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wings with the under feathers forward, and alighted by the bank of the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: broad Flavro that divides the city of Nombros. And down the bank of the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Flavro he fluttered low, like to a hawk over a new-cut cornfield when the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: little creatures of the corn are shelterless, and at the same time down
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the other bank the Death from the gods went mowing.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "At once they saw each other, and the angel glared at the Death, and the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Death leered back at him, and the flames in the eyes of the angel
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: illumined with a red glare the mist that lay in the hollows of the sockets
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the Death. Suddenly they fell on one another, sword to scythe. And the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: angel captured the temples of the gods, and set up over them the sign of
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: God, and the Death captured the temples of God, and led into them the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ceremonies and sacrifices of the gods; and all the while the centuries
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: slipped quietly by, going down the Flavro seawards.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "And now some worship God in the temple of the gods, and others worship the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: gods in the temple of God, and still the angel hath not returned again to
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the rejoicing choirs, and still the Death hath not gone back to die with
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the dead gods; but all through Nombros they fight up and down, and still
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: on each side of the Flavro the city lives."
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the watchers in the gate said, "Enter in."
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then another traveler rose up, and said:
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Solemnly between Huhenwazy and Nitcrana the huge grey clouds came
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: floating. And those great mountains, heavenly Huhenwazi and Nitcrana, the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: king of peaks, greeted them, calling them brothers. And the clouds were
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: glad of their greeting, for they meet with companions seldom in the lonely
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: heights of the sky.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "But the vapours of evening said unto the earth-mist, 'What are those
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: shapes that dare to move above us and to go where Nitcrana is and
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Huhenwazi?'
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "And the earth-mist said in answer unto the vapours of evening, 'It is
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: only an earth-mist that has become mad and has left the warm and
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: comfortable earth, and has in his madness thought that his place is with
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Huhenwazi and Nitcrana.'
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "'Once,' said the vapours of evening, 'there were clouds, but this was
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: many and many a day ago, as our forefathers have said. Perhaps the mad one
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: thinks he is the clouds.'
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Then spake the earth-worms from the warm deeps of the mud, saying 'O
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: earth-mist, thou art indeed the clouds, and there are no clouds but thou.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And as for Huhenwazi and Nitcrana, I cannot see them, and therefore they
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: are not high, and there are no mountains in the world but those that I
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: cast up every morning out of the deeps of the mud.'
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "And the earth-mist and the vapours of evening were glad at the voice of
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the earth-worms, and looking earthward believed what they had said.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "And indeed it is better to be as the earth-mist, and to keep close to the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: warm mud at night, and to hear the earth-worm's comfortable speech, and
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: not to be a wanderer in the cheerless heights, but to leave the mountains
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: alone with their desolate snow, to draw what comfort they can from their
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: vast aspect over all the cities of men, and from the whispers that they
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hear at evening of unknown distant gods."
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the watchers in the gate said, "Enter in."
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then a man stood up who came out of the west, and told a western tale. He
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: said:
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "There is a road in Rome that runs through an ancient temple that once the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: gods had loved; it runs along the top of a great wall, and the floor of
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the temple lies far down beneath it, of marble, pink and white.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Upon the temple floor I counted to the number of thirteen hungry cats.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "'Sometimes,' they said among themselves, 'it was the gods that lived
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: here, sometimes it was men, and now it's cats. So let us enjoy the sun on
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the hot marble before another people comes.'
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "For it was at that hour of a warm afternoon when my fancy is able to hear
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: silent voices.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "And the awful leanness of all those thirteen cats moved me to go into a
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: neighbouring fish shop, and there to buy a quantity of fishes. Then I
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: returned and threw them all over the railing at the top of the great wall,
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and they fell for thirty feet, and hit the sacred marble with a smack.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Now, in any other town but Rome, or in the minds of any other cats, the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sight of fishes falling out of heaven had surely excited wonder. They rose
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: slowly, and all stretched themselves, then they came leisurely towards the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: fishes. 'It is only a miracle,' they said in their hearts."
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the watchers in the gate said, "Enter in."
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Proudly and slowly, as they spoke, drew up to them a camel, whose rider
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sought entrance to the city. His face shone with the sunset by which for
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: long he had steered for the city's gate. Of him they demanded toll.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Whereat he spoke to his camel, and the camel roared and kneeled, and the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: man descended from him. And the man unwrapped from many silks a box of
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: divers metals wrought by the Japanese, and on the lid of it were figures
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of men who gazed from some shore at an isle of the Inland Sea. This he
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: showed to the watchers, and when they had seen it, said, "It has seemed to
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: me that these speak to each other thus:
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "'Behold now Oojni, the dear one of the sea, the little mother sea that
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hath no storms. She goeth out from Oojni singing a song, and she returneth
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: singing over her sands. Little is Oojni in the lap of the sea, and scarce
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to be perceived by wondering ships. White sails have never wafted her
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: legends afar, they are told not by bearded wanderers of the sea. Her
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: fireside tales are known not to the North, the dragons of China have not
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: heard of them, nor those that ride on elephants through Ind.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "'Men tell the tales and the smoke ariseth upwards; the smoke departeth
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and the tales are told.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "'Oojni is not a name among the nations, she is not know of where the
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: merchants meet, she is not spoken of by alien lips.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "'Indeed, but Oojni is a little among the isles, yet is she loved by those
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that know her coasts and her inland places hidden from the sea.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Without glory, without fame, and without wealth, Oojni is greatly loved
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: by a little people, and by a few; yet not by few, for all her dead still

title: A Dreamer's Tales

text: THE HASHISH MAN

author: Dunsany, Lord

text: I was at a dinner in London the other day. The ladies had gone upstairs,
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and no one sat on my right; on my left there was a man I did not know, but
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: he knew my name somehow apparently, for he turned to me after a while, and
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: said, "I read a story of yours about Bethmoora in a review."
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Of course I remembered the tale. It was about a beautiful Oriental city
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that was suddenly deserted in a day--nobody quite knew why. I said, "Oh,
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: yes," and slowly searched in my mind for some more fitting acknowledgment
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of the compliment that his memory had paid me.

title: A Dreamer's Tales

text: sickness; it was not that at all."
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: I said, "Why! Have you been there?"
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And he said, "Yes; I do it with hashish. I know Bethmoora well." And he
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: took out of his pocket a small box full of some black stuff that looked
title: A Dreamer's Tales

title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "He had a lot of it, as it had killed his father." But I interrupted him,
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: for I wanted to know for certain what it was that had made desolate that
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: beautiful city, Bethmoora, and why they fled from it swiftly in a day.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: A Dreamer's Tales

title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: A Dreamer's Tales

title: A Dreamer's Tales

title: A Dreamer's Tales

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: A Dreamer's Tales

title: A Dreamer's Tales

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: A Dreamer's Tales

title: A Dreamer's Tales

title: A Dreamer's Tales

title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and led them on again; and a few faithful servants stayed with them still.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: A Dreamer's Tales

title: A Dreamer's Tales

title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: A Dreamer's Tales

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: A Dreamer's Tales

author: Dunsany, Lord

text: forest.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: letting it run a little way and overtaking it with a paw.
title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: A Dreamer's Tales
author: Dunsany, Lord
